The U.S. Department of Labor (DOL) is providing this App as a public service. This App is advisory in nature and informational in content. It is not a standard or regulation, and it neither creates new legal obligations nor alters existing obligations created by OSHA standards or the Occupational Safety and Health Act. Pursuant to the OSH Act, employers must comply with safety and health standards and regulations issued and enforced either by OSHA or by an OSHA-approved State Plan. In addition, the Act's General Duty Clause, Section 5(a)(1), requires employers to provide their employees with a workplace free from recognized hazards likely to cause death or serious physical harm.

This App is a service that is continually under development and it does not include every possible heat-related situation encountered in the workplace. The user should be aware that, while OSHA will try to keep the information timely and accurate, there may be a delay between official publication of OSHA materials and the modification of this App. The Federal Register and the Code of Federal Regulations remain the official sources for regulatory information published by OSHA. Further, the calculations performed by this App rely on the accuracy of the data provided by the user. Therefore, OSHA cannot guarantee that these calculations accurately reflect conditions at a particular worksite.

This App can, at the user's discretion, obtain weather-related data directly from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) based on the user's current location (for GPS-enabled phones). The information transmitted to NOAA through this App, including the user's location, is only used to generate data to transmit to the user through the App and is not retransmitted to OSHA or any other entity for any other purpose.

Heat stroke symptoms: red, hot, dry skin or excessive sweating, very high body temperature, confusion, seizures, and fainting.
Heat exhaustion symptoms: cool, moist skin, heavy sweating, headache, nausea or vomiting, dizziness, light headedness, weakness, thirst, irritability, and fast heart beat.
Heat cramps symptoms: muscle spasms, pain, usually in abdomen, arms, or legs.
Heat rash symptoms: clusters of red bumps on skin, and often appears on neck, upper chest, folds of skin.

Heat stroke first aid: HEAT STROKE IS A MEDICAL EMERGENCY. Call 911. While waiting for help: Place worker in shady, cool area, Loosen clothing, remove outer clothing, Fan air on worker; cool packs in armpits, Wet worker with cool water; apply ice packs, cool compresses, or ice if available, Provide fluids (preferably water) as soon as possible, and Stay with worker until help arrives.

Heat exhaustion first aid: Have worker sit or lie down in a cool, shady area, Give worker plenty of water or other cool beverages to drink, Cool worker with cold compresses/ice packs, Take to clinic or emergency room for medical evaluation and treatment if signs or symptoms worsen or do not improve within 60 minutes, and Do not return to work that day.

Heat cramps first aid: Have worker rest in shady, cool area, Have worker drink water or other cool beverages, Wait a few hours before allowing worker to return to heavy work, and Seek medical attention if cramps don\'t go away.
Heat rash first aid: Try to work in a cooler, less humid environment when possible, and Keep the affected area dry.
* Remember, if you are not a medical professional, use this information as a guide only to help protect workers in need.

Drink water throughout the day.


Estimate how much water will be needed and decide who will obtain and check on water supplies.

Guidelines recommend that outdoor workers drink 4 cups (8 cones) of water every hour, even if they're not thirsty.

It is best to drink a small amount of water often, like 1 cup (2 cones) every 15 minutes.

Avoid alcohol and drinks with caffeine or sugar.

Generally, fluid intake should not exceed 6 cups per hour.

Know what to do in an emergency. Have a plan in case a worker experiences heat-related illness. Everyone onsite should know the procedures for responding to possible heat illness:


What steps to follow if a worker has signs of heat illness.

Who to call for medical help and how to give clear directions to the worksite if calling 911.

Who will provide first aid until the ambulance arrives.

Train workers before hot outdoor work begins. Tailor training to cover worksite-specific conditions. Address the following topics:


Risk factors for heat-related illness.

Different types of heat-related illness and how to recognize them.

Heat-related illness prevention procedures, including drinking water.

Importance of acclimatization and how your worksite procedures address it.

The importance and method of responding to possible heat-related illness, including immediately reporting signs or symptoms to the supervisor.

Procedures to follow when contacting emergency medical services, including providing clear directions to the worksite.

Pace the work and build up gradually to the heaviest work (called acclimatization). People can, to a large extent, adjust to heat. Some important reminders:


New workers and those returning from an absence of two or more weeks should have a 5-day minimum adjustment period.

Closely supervise new employees for the first 14 days or until they are fully acclimatized.

Some workers require up to 2-3 weeks to fully acclimatize.

Acclimatization is essential for all workers during a heat wave.

When possible, allow only acclimatized workers to perform the more strenuous tasks.

Modify work/rest periods to give the body a chance to get rid of excess heat. Assign new and un-acclimatized workers lighter work and longer rest periods. Shorten work periods and increase rest periods:


As temperature, humidity, and sunshine increase.

When there is no air movement or if protective clothing or gear is worn.

For heavier work.

Monitor workers for signs and symptoms of heat illness.


Check routinely to make sure workers are making use of water and shade and not experiencing heat-related symptoms.

Monitor new workers and unacclimatized workers more closely.

For workers wearing heavy or non-breathable clothing or during extreme heat conditions, check for physical signs (e.g., body temperature, heart rate) of possible over exposure to the heat.
Precautions
Most people can work safely. These good practice reminders can help:\n

Drinking water must be on site.\n
Drink plenty of water, even if you\'re not thirsty.

Make sure medical help (clinic, hospital, emergency services) is nearby – if not, first aid must be on site.\n
Know where you are in case you need to call 911.

Gradually build up workload and allow more breaks over the first week for new or returning workers doing heavy work (acclimatize workers).\n
Use more precautions for layers of protective clothing and work in direct sun.\n
Use sunscreen and wear light-colored clothing.

Train on the signs and symptoms of heat illness and what to do in an emergency.\n
Plan ahead for hotter weather.
Workers can be at increased risk for heat illness. Important reminders:\n

Drinking water must be on site.\n
Drink plenty of water, even if you’re not thirsty – every 15 minutes (about 4 cups/hour).\n
Set up cool, shaded rest areas.

Make sure medical help (clinic, hospital, emergency services) is nearby – if not, first aid must be on site.\n
Call 911 and cool a worker who is unconscious, confused, or uncoordinated. This may be heat stroke, which is a medical emergency.\n
Know where you are in case you need to call 911.

• Develop and follow work/rest schedules (amount of work time and rest time each work hour).

Conditions are hazardous. Extra measures are recommended. Alert everyone of high risk conditions and review protective measures. A designated knowledgeable person should be on site to modify work activities and set work/rest schedules.

Reminders to help keep workers safe (see OSHA's heat illness campaign site for more information and resources):

Drinking water must be on site.\n
Drink plenty of cool water, even if you\'re not thirsty – every 15 minutes (about 4 cups/hour).\n
Set up cool, shaded rest areas.

Make sure medical help (clinic, hospital, emergency services) is nearby – if not, first aid must be on site.\n
Call 911 and cool a worker who is unconscious, confused, or uncoordinated. This may be heat stroke, which is a medical emergency.\n
Know where you are in case you need to call 911.

Gradually build up the workload and allow more breaks over a week (acclimatize workers).

Establish and follow a work/rest schedule (amount of work time and rest time each work hour):
• Take routine rest breaks in cool, shaded area.
• Remove protective clothing (if possible) while resting.
• Increase rest time as heat index rises or if workers show signs of heat illness.

Adjust work activities:
• Do heavy tasks earlier in the day.
• Decrease the pace of heavy job tasks.
• Look for other ways to adjust work activities (add more workers, rotate jobs).

Use more precautions for work in layers of protective clothing and in the direct sun - see OSHA's heat illness campaign site.

Use sunscreen and wear light-colored clothing.

Watch out for each other.\n

Supervisors should maintain communications at all times with crew and watch for signs of heat illness.

Conditions are dangerous! Heat illness can develop faster and be more serious at this risk level. Extra measures are recommended.

Reschedule all non-essential work for days when the heat index is lower. Move essential work to the coolest part of the day – start earlier, split the work shift, or work evening/night shifts.

If emergency or essential work must be done at this heat index, then a designated knowledgeable person should be on-site to modify work activities and set work/rest schedules. STOP WORK if protective measures are not possible.

Important reminders (see OSHA's heat illness campaign site for more information and resources):

Drinking water must be on site. Establish a water drinking schedule (about 4 cups/hour).\n
Set up cool, shaded rest areas.

Make sure medical help (clinic, hospital, emergency services) is nearby – if not, first aid must be on site.\n
Call 911 and cool a worker who is unconscious, confused, or uncoordinated. This may be heat stroke, which is a medical emergency.\n
Know where you are in case you need to call 911.

Gradually build up the workload and allow more breaks over a week (acclimatize workers).

Establish and follow a work/rest schedule (amount of work time and rest time each work hour):
• Take routine rest breaks in cool, shaded area.
• Remove protective clothing (if possible) while resting.
• Increase rest time as heat index rises or if workers show signs of heat illness.

Adjust work activities:
• Do heavy tasks earlier in the day.
• Decrease the pace of heavy job tasks.
• Add more workers to heavy job tasks.
• Rotate workers between heavy and lighter jobs.

Provide cooling measures (cool vests, cool mist stations).

Use more precautions for work in layers of protective clothing and the direct sun - see OSHA's heat illness campaign site.

Use sunscreen and wear light-colored clothing.

Alert all workers of extreme heat hazard.

Review heat-related illness topics with workers before work begins:
• How to recognize heat-related illness.
• How to prevent it.
• What to do if someone gets sick.

Check heart rate, temperature, or other physical signs of heat exposure at rest breaks.\n
Watch out for each other.\n
Set up a buddy system.\n
Supervisors should maintain communications at all times with crew and watch for signs of heat illness.
